For global settings such as colors, I'd recommend to use theme values only in the css. Doing so will allow you to have a single place with color settings.
Usually when creating a theme that should be used several times(e.g Marketplace or several brandkits), you want to utilize brand settings since it's a good starting point. If you're creating a theme for a single purpose, you don't need to rely on brand settings. This means:
If you want to disable the "linkage" to a brandkit, simply remove the "inherited_value"... part from a color field.

The best practise for brand settings&theme settings inheritance is:
brand settings -> theme settings -> CSS
So brand settings are inherited to theme settings and can be overwritten by them. The result from the theme settings is put to the CSS. This ensures that you have only one source of information

Okay, thanks for the input! So truly, I can't control/change the brandkit colors (primary color for example) in the theme editor. Even though it shows up in the theme editor?

That's my main holdup.

Yes and no. :sweat_smile: 
You cannot change the value of the color in the brandkit settings via theme settings, but if you inherit the brand kit color into the theme you can overwrite the value in the theme settings. The most important part is to use {{ theme.}} in your css instead of {{ brand_settings.}}}

Got it, that makes sense! That's where I was struggling.. especially since the brandkit colors show up in the theme editor. Just feel like I should have control there as well if it's going to show up. THANK YOU!
I think the purpose is that the brand kit is the source of truth, you can use it in a theme or override it for that theme, but you can't change the brand kit colors without editing it directly.
